raw_text: ROUGE utilizes? skip n-grams?, which allow for matches of sequences of words that are not necessarily adjacent (Lin and Och, 2004a) .METEOR uses the Porterstemmer and synonym matching via WordNet to calculate recall and precision more accurately (Banerjee and Lavie, 2005) .The HWC metrics compare dependency and constituency trees for both reference and machine translations (Liu and Gildea, 2005)

raw_text: Metrics in the Rouge family allow for skip n-grams (Lin and Och,2004a); Kauchak and Barzilay (2006) take para phrasing into account; metrics such as METEOR (Banerjee and Lavie, 2005) and GTM (Melamedetal., 2003) calculate both recall and precision; ME TEOR is also similar to SIA (Liu and Gildea, 2006) in that word class information is used
clean_text: Metrics in the Rouge family allow for skip n-grams (Lin and Och,2004a); Kauchak and Barzilay (2006) take para phrasing into account; metrics such as METEOR (Banerjee and Lavie, 2005) and GTM (Melamedetal., 2003) calculate both recall and precision; ME TEOR is also similar to SIA (Liu and Gildea, 2006) in that word class information is used.

raw_text: While the F measure over Precision and Recall satisfies these constraints1 ,precision and recall in isolation do not satisfy all of them: maximum recall can be achieved without resembling the gold standard text decomposition; and maximum precision can be achieved with only a few overlapped elements.BLEU (Papineni et al, 2001a) computes the n gram precision while the metric ROUGE (LinandOch, 2004a) computes the n-gram recall
clean_text: While the F measure over Precision and Recall satisfies these constraints, precision and recall in isolation do not satisfy all of them: maximum recall can be achieved without resembling the gold standard text decomposition; and maximum precision can be achieved with only a few overlapped elements.BLEU (Papineni et al, 2001a) computes the n gram precision while the metric ROUGE (LinandOch, 2004a) computes the n-gram recall.
